V. Dortmund''', often known simply as '''Borussia Dortmund''' ({{IPA-de|boˈʁʊsi̯aː ˈdɔɐ̯tmʊnt|-|De-Borussia Dortmund.ogg}}){{Citation |last=Mangold |first=Max|year=2005 |title=Das Aussprachewörterbuch|publisher=Duden |isbn=978-3-411-04066-7|pages=212 and 282}} or by its initialism '''BVB''' ({{IPA-de|beːfaʊ̯ˈbeː|pron|De-BVB.ogg}}), is a German professional [[sports club]] based in [[Dortmund]], [[North Rhine-Westphalia]]. It is best known for its men's professional [[football club (association football)|football]] team, which plays in the [[Bundesliga]], the top tier of the [[German football league system]]. The club have won eight [[List of German football champions|league championships]], five [[DFB-Pokal]]s, one [[UEFA Champions League]], one [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]], and one [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]]. Founded in 1909 by eighteen football players from Dortmund, the football team is part of a large membership-based sports club with more than 189,000 members in 2023,{{Cite web |last=Hintermüller |first=Marco |date=2023-11-27 |title=Borussia Dortmund bemerkt besorgniserregende Entwicklung – "Finde ich bedenklich" |url=https://www.derwesten.de/sport/fussball/bvb/borussia-dortmund-bvb-mitgliederversammlung-mitglieder-news-id300735117.html |access-date=2024-01-29 |website=DerWesten.de |language=de-DE}} making Borussia Dortmund the [[List of sports clubs by membership|fifth largest sports club by membership]] in the world. The club also has a [[Borussia Dortmund Handball|women's handball]] team. Since 1974, Dortmund have played their home games at the [[Westfalenstadion]]; the stadium is the largest in Germany, and Dortmund has the highest average attendance of any [[Football club (association football)|association football club]] in the world.{{Cite web|url=https://talksport.com/football/525568/top-50-average-football-attendances-in-the-world-in-the-last-five-years-including-manchester-united-barcelona-and-borussia-dortmund/|title=The top 50 average attendances in football over the last five years|date=12 April 2019|access-date=21 February 2020|archive-date=21 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200221065947/https://talksport.com/football/525568/top-50-average-football-attendances-in-the-world-in-the-last-five-years-including-manchester-united-barcelona-and-borussia-dortmund/|url-status=live}} Borussia Dortmund's colours are black and yellow, giving the club its nickname ''die Schwarzgelben''.{{cite web |url= http://www.puma.com/football/teams/42-borussia-dortmund |title= Borussia Dortmund – Puma SE |work= puma.com |publisher= [[Puma SE]] |access-date= 17 August 2013 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140113053901/http://www.puma.com/football/teams/42-borussia-dortmund |archive-date= 13 January 2014 |url-status=dead |df= dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/teamsandplayers/teams/club=52758/profile/index.html|title=Borussia Dortmund|publisher=[[UEFA]]|access-date=17 August 2013|archive-date=19 August 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130819004812/http://www.uefa.com/teamsandplayers/teams/club=52758/profile/index.html|url-status=live}} They hold a long-standing rivalry with [[Ruhr]] neighbours [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]], against whom they contest the [[Revierderby]]. They also contest [[Der Klassiker]] with [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]. In terms of [[Deloitte]]'s annual [[Deloitte Football Money League|Football Money League]], Dortmund was in 2021 ranked as the second richest sports club in Germany, and the 12th richest football team in the world.{{cite web| title = Deloitte Football Money League 2022 (rankings for the 2020–21 season)| url = https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/uk/Documents/sports-business-group/deloitte-uk-dfml22.pdf| website = www2.deloitte.com| access-date = 17 November 2022| archive-date = 23 November 2022| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20221123185955/https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/uk/Documents/sports-business-group/deloitte-uk-dfml22.pdf| url-status = live}} Moreover, under the directorship of [[Michael Zorc]] in the 2010s, Dortmund have cultivated a reputation for spotting and developing young talent, and have remained focused on developing a [[youth system]].{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/why-borussia-dortmund-not-so-secret-recipe-for-success-so-hard-to-copy-a4110971.html|title=Why Borussia Dortmund's not-so-secret recipe for success is so hard to copy|date=6 April 2019|publisher=Standard|access-date=3 February 2020|archive-date=3 February 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200203153130/https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/why-borussia-dortmund-not-so-secret-recipe-for-success-so-hard-to-copy-a4110971.html|url-status=live}} ==History== ===Foundation and early years=== [[File:Borussia dortmund 1913.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|Borussia Dortmund in 1913]] The club was founded on 19 December 1909 by a group of young men unhappy with the Catholic church-sponsored ''Trinity Youth'', where they played football under the stern and unsympathetic eye{{tone inline|date=January 2024}} of the local parish priest. The priest, Father Dewald was blocked at the door when he tried to break up the organising meeting being held in a room of the local pub, ''Zum Wildschütz''. The founders were Franz and Paul Braun, Henry Cleve, Hans Debest, Paul Dziendzielle, Franz, Julius and Wilhelm Jacobi, Hans Kahn, Gustav Müller, Franz Risse, Fritz Schulte, Hans Siebold, August Tönnesmann, Heinrich and Robert Unger, Fritz Weber and Franz Wendt. The name ''Borussia'' is [[Latin]] for [[Prussia]] but was taken from Borussia beer from the nearby Borussia brewery in Dortmund.{{cite web| url=http://www.bvb.de/eng/BVB/History/1909| title=A turbulent founding on 19/12/1909| website=BVB Club Website| access-date=9 August 2014| archive-date=18 October 2015| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018090111/http://www.bvb.de/eng/BVB/History/1909| url-status=live}} The team began playing in blue and white striped shirts with a red sash, and black shorts.{{citation needed|date=January 2024}} In 1913, they donned the black and yellow stripes for the first time. Over the next decades the club had only modest success playing in local leagues. They had a brush{{tone inline|date=January 2024}} with bankruptcy in 1929 when an attempt to boost the club's fortunes by signing some paid professional footballers failed miserably and left the team deep in debt. They survived only through the generosity of a local supporter who covered the team's shortfall out of his own pocket. The 1930s saw the rise of the [[Third Reich]], which restructured sports and football organisations throughout the nation to suit the regime's goals. ''Borussia'''s president was replaced when he refused to join the [[Nazi Party]], and a couple of members who surreptitiously used the club's offices to produce anti-Nazi pamphlets were executed in the last days of the war. The club did have greater success in the newly established [[Gauliga Westfalen]], but would have to wait until after the [[World War II|Second World War]] to make a breakthrough. It was during this time that Borussia developed its intense rivalry with [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] of suburban [[Gelsenkirchen]], the most successful side of the era (see ''[[Revierderby]]''). Like every other organisation in Germany, Borussia was dissolved by the Allied occupation authorities after the war in an attempt to distance the country's institutions from its recent Nazi past. There was a short-lived attempt to merge the club with two others – ''Werksportgemeinschaft Hoesch'' and ''Freier Sportverein 98'' – as ''Sportgemeinschaft Borussia von 1898'', but it was as ''Ballspiel-Verein Borussia'' (''BVB'') that they made their first appearance in the national league final in 1949, where they lost 2–3 to [[VfR Mannheim]].{{citation needed|date=December 2014}} ===First national titles=== [[File:Borussia Dortmund Performance Chart.png|450px|thumb|Historical chart of Borussia Dortmund league performance]] Between 1946 and 1963, Borussia featured in the [[Oberliga West (1947–63)|Oberliga West]], a first division league which dominated German football through the late 1950s. In [[1949 German football championship|1949]], Borussia reached the [[1949 German football championship#Final|final]] in [[Stuttgart]] against [[VfR Mannheim]], which they lost 2–3 after extra time. The club claimed its first national title in [[1956 German football championship|1956]] with a 4–2 win against [[Karlsruher SC]]. One year later, Borussia defeated [[Hamburger SV]] 4–1 to win their [[1957 German football championship|second national title]]. After this coup,{{tone inline|date=January 2024}} the three Alfredos ([[Alfred Preißler]], [[Alfred Kelbassa]] and [[Alfred Niepieklo]]) were legends{{tone inline|date=January 2024}} in Dortmund. In [[1963 German football championship|1963]], Borussia won the last edition of the [[List of German football champions#German football championships Postwar to the Bundesliga (1946–63)|German Football Championship]] (before the introduction of the new [[Bundesliga]]) to secure their third national title. ===Bundesliga debut=== In 1962, the [[German Football Association|DFB]] met in Dortmund and voted to establish a professional football league in Germany, to begin play in August 1963 as the [[Bundesliga]]. Borussia Dortmund earned its place among the first sixteen clubs to play in the league by winning the last pre-Bundesliga national championship. Runners-up [[1. FC Köln]] also earned an automatic berth. Dortmund's [[Friedhelm Konietzka]] scored the first-ever Bundesliga goal a minute into the match, which they would eventually lose 2–3 to [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]]. In [[1964–65 DFB-Pokal|1965]], Dortmund won its first [[DFB-Pokal]]. In 1966, Dortmund won the [[1965–66 European Cup Winners' Cup|European Cup Winners' Cup]] 2–1 against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in extra time, with the goals coming from [[Sigfried Held]] and [[Reinhard Libuda]]. In the same year, however, the team surrendered a commanding position atop{{tone inline|date=January 2024}} the [[1965–66 Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] by losing four of their last five league games and finishing second, three points behind champions [[TSV 1860 München|1860 München]]. Ironically,{{according to whom|date=January 2024}} much of 1860 München's success came on the strength of the play of Konietzka, recently transferred from Dortmund. The 1970s were characterised by financial problems, relegation from the Bundesliga in 1972, and the opening of the [[Westfalenstadion]], named after its home region [[Westphalia]] in 1974. The club returned to the Bundesliga in 1976. Dortmund continued to have financial problems through the 1980s. ''BVB'' avoided being relegated in 1986 by winning a third decisive playoff game against [[SC Fortuna Köln|Fortuna Köln]] after finishing the regular season in 16th place. Dortmund did not enjoy{{tone inline|date=January 2024}} any significant success again until a 4–1 DFB-Pokal win in [[1988–89 DFB-Pokal|1989]] against Werder Bremen. It was [[Horst Köppel]]'s first trophy as a manager.{{citation needed|date=January 2024}} Dortmund then won the [[1989 DFB-Supercup|1989 DFL-Supercup]] 4–3 against rivals [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]. ===Golden age – the 1990s=== After a tenth-place finish in the Bundesliga in [[1990–91 Bundesliga|1991]], manager [[Horst Köppel]] was sacked and manager [[Ottmar Hitzfeld]] was hired. In [[1991–92 Bundesliga|1992]], Hitzfeld led Borussia Dortmund to a second-place finish in the Bundesliga, and would have won the title had [[VfB Stuttgart]] not won their last game to become champions instead. Along with a fourth-place finish in the Bundesliga, Dortmund made it to the 1993 [[1992–93 UEFA Cup|UEFA Cup]] [[1993 UEFA Cup final|final]], which they lost 6–1 on aggregate to [[Juventus FC|Juventus]]. In spite of this result, Borussia walked away with [[Deutsche Mark|DM]]25 million under the prize money pool system in place at the time for German sides participating in the Cup. Cash flush,{{tone inline|date=January 2024}} Dortmund was able to sign players who later brought them numerous honours in the 1990s. Under the [[Captain (association football)|captaincy]] of 1996 [[Ballon d'Or|European Footballer of the Year]] [[Matthias Sammer]], Borussia Dortmund won back-to-back Bundesliga titles in [[1994–95 Bundesliga|1995]] and [[1995–96 Bundesliga|1996]]. Dortmund also won the [[DFL-Supercup]] against [[Borussia Mönchengladbach|Mönchengladbach]] in [[1995 DFB-Supercup|1995]] and [[1. FC Kaiserslautern]] in [[1996 DFB-Supercup|1996]]. In [[1996–97 UEFA Champions League|1996–97]] the team reached its first [[List of European Cup and UEFA Champions League finals|European Cup final]]. In a memorable [[1997 UEFA Champions League final|match]] at the [[Olympic Stadium (Munich)|Olympiastadion]] in [[Munich]], Dortmund faced the holders Juventus. [[Karl-Heinz Riedle]] put Dortmund ahead, shooting under goalkeeper [[Angelo Peruzzi]] from a cross by [[Paul Lambert]]. Riedle then made it two with a bullet header from a corner kick. In the second half, [[Alessandro Del Piero]] pulled one back for Juventus with a back heel. Then 20-year-old substitute and Dortmund-born [[Lars Ricken]] latched onto a through pass by [[Andreas Möller]]. Only 16 seconds after coming on to the pitch, Ricken chipped Peruzzi in the Juventus goal from over 20 yards out with his first touch of the ball. With [[Zinedine Zidane]] unable to make an impression for Juventus against the close marking of Lambert,{{cite web|url=http://www.espnstar.com/rss-feed/detail/item617249/ |title=Paul Lambert – The Norwich wizard |date=4 May 2011 |publisher=ESPN |access-date=28 November 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223063347/http://www.espnstar.com/rss-feed/detail/item617249/ |archive-date=23 December 2011 }}{{cite news | url = http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/english-football/norwich-city-manager-paul-lambert-on-his-vision-for-the-future-1.917708 | title = Norwich City manager Paul Lambert on his vision for the future | work = Sunday Herald | date = 6 September 2009 | access-date = 28 November 2011 | archive-date = 28 May 2013 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130528015254/http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/english-football/norwich-city-manager-paul-lambert-on-his-vision-for-the-future-1.917708 | url-status = live }}{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2011/nov/25/joy-of-six-football-exports | title = Revealed: The Joy of Six: British and Irish footballers abroad | work = The Guardian | location = London | date = 25 November 2011 | access-date = 28 November 2011 | archive-date = 4 November 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20201104081219/https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2011/nov/25/joy-of-six-football-exports | url-status = live }} Dortmund lifted the trophy with a 3–1 victory. Hitzfeld's successful managerial reign then ended, with [[Nevio Scala]] being appointed as his successor. Dortmund then beat Brazilian club [[Cruzeiro Esporte Clube|Cruzeiro]] 2–0 in the [[1997 Intercontinental Cup]] final to become world club champions.{{cite web |url = https://www.rsssf.org/tablest/toyota97.html |title = Intercontinental Club Cup 1997 |first = Marcelo |last = Leme de Arruda |publisher = [[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation]] |date = 2 August 1999 |access-date = 7 May 2012 |archive-date = 9 September 2022 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20220909140237/https://www.rsssf.org/tablest/toyota97.html |url-status = live }} Borussia Dortmund were the second German club to win the Intercontinental Cup, after Bayern Munich in [[1976 Intercontinental Cup|1976]].{{cite web |url= http://www.theoriginalwinger.com/2013-04-23-borussia-dortmund-v-real-madrid-champions-league-preview |title= Borussia Dortmund v Real Madrid – Champions League Preview |work= theoriginalwinger.com |date= 23 April 2013 |access-date= 17 August 2013 |archive-date= 13 September 2013 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130913231146/http://theoriginalwinger.com/2013-04-23-borussia-dortmund-v-real-madrid-champions-league-preview |url-status= live }} As defending champions, Dortmund reached the Champions League semi-final in 1998. The team was missing key players from the start of the season when they played [[Real Madrid CF|Real Madrid]] in the 1998 semi-final.{{vague|date=January 2024|reason='semi-final'? was the '98 semi' at the start of the season? or is that about the 'key players'?}} Sammer's career was shortened by injury and only played three first team games after the 1997 Champions League win. Lambert had left in November to return to play in Scotland. Möller missed the first leg as did Kohler who missed both games in the tie. Real won the first leg 2–0 at home. Dortmund played better in the second leg, but did not take their chances. The club exited 2–0 on aggregate.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=1942584.html|title=Chapuisat: Dortmund v Madrid will be 'incredible'|publisher=UEFA|date=22 April 2013|access-date=11 December 2016|archive-date=21 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221151656/http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=1942584.html|url-status=live}} ===21st century and Borussia "goes public"=== [[File:Borussia Dortmund Team 2007 08.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|Borussia Dortmund in 2007]] In October 2000, Borussia Dortmund became the first publicly traded club on the German stock market.{{cite news |title=Borussia Dortmund fans and investors aren't on the same team |url=https://www.dw.com/en/borussia-dortmund-fans-and-investors-arent-on-the-same-team/a-15074555-1 |access-date=12 July 2018 |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=13 May 2011 |archive-date=13 July 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180713013924/https://www.dw.com/en/borussia-dortmund-fans-and-investors-arent-on-the-same-team/a-15074555-1 |url-status=live }} In [[2001–02 Bundesliga|2002]], Borussia Dortmund won their third Bundesliga title. Dortmund had a remarkable run at the end of the season to overtake [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen|Bayer Leverkusen]], securing the title on the final day. Manager [[Matthias Sammer]] became the first person in Borussia Dortmund history to win the Bundesliga as both a player and manager.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiatoday.intoday.in/story/champions-league-final-2013-bayern-munich-vs-borussia-dortmund-match-preview-facts-key-players/1/272818.html|title=Bayern Munich vs Borussia Dortmund: The first all-German Champions League final|work=India Today|date=24 May 2013|access-date=17 August 2013|archive-date=25 August 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200825165806/https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/football/story/champions-league-final-2013-bayern-munich-vs-borussia-dortmund-match-preview-facts-key-players-164244-2013-05-24|url-status=live}} In the same season, Borussia lost the [[2002 UEFA Cup final|final]] of the [[2001–02 UEFA Cup]] to the Dutch club [[Feyenoord]]. Dortmund's fortunes then steadily declined for several years. Poor financial management led to a heavy debt load and the sale of their Westfalenstadion grounds. The situation was compounded by failure to advance in the [[2003–04 UEFA Champions League]], when the team was eliminated on penalties in the qualifying rounds by [[Club Brugge KV|Club Brugge]]. In 2003, Bayern Munich loaned €2 million to Dortmund for several months to pay their payroll. Borussia was again driven to the brink of [[bankruptcy]] in 2005, the original €11 value of its shares having plummeted{{tone inline|date=January 2024}} by over 80% on the [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange]]. At this time [[Hans-Joachim Watzke]] was appointed CEO and streamlined the club. The response to the crisis included a 20% pay cut for all players.{{cite web |author=Von abendblatt.de |url=http://www.abendblatt.de/sport/fussball/article2179798/Hoeness-plaudert-Haben-BVB-zwei-Millionen-Euro-geliehen.html |title=Pikantes Geheimnis – Hoeneß plaudert: "Haben BVB zwei Millionen Euro geliehen" – Sport – Fußball – Hamburger Abendblatt |date=6 February 2012 |publisher=Abendblatt.de |language=de |access-date=5 March 2013 |archive-date=7 March 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130307220216/http://www.abendblatt.de/sport/fussball/article2179798/Hoeness-plaudert-Haben-BVB-zwei-Millionen-Euro-geliehen.html |url-status=live }} In 2006, in order to reduce debt, the [[Westfalenstadion]] was renamed "Signal Iduna Park" after a local insurance company. The naming rights agreement ran until 2021. Dortmund suffered a miserable start to the [[2005–06 Bundesliga|2005–06]] season, but rallied to finish seventh. The club was unable gain a place in the [[2006–07 UEFA Cup|UEFA Cup]] via the Fair Play draw. The club's management indicated that the club again showed a profit; this was largely related to the sale of [[David Odonkor]] to [[Real Betis]] and [[Tomáš Rosický]] to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. In the [[2006–07 Bundesliga|2006–07]] season, Dortmund unexpectedly faced serious [[Promotion and relegation|relegation]] trouble for the first time in years. Dortmund went through three coaches, and appointed [[Thomas Doll]] on 13 March 2007, after dropping to just one point above the relegation zone. [[Christoph Metzelder]] also left Borussia Dortmund on a free transfer. In the [[2007–08 Bundesliga|2007–08]] season, Dortmund finished 13th in the Bundesliga table, but reached the [[2007–08 DFB-Pokal|DFB-Pokal]] final against Bayern Munich, where they lost 2–1 in extra time. The final appearance qualified Dortmund for the [[2008–09 UEFA Cup|UEFA Cup]], because Bayern had already qualified for the [[2008–09 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]].{{citation needed|date=January 2024}} Thomas Doll resigned on 19 May 2008 and was replaced by [[Jürgen Klopp]]. ===Klopp era and return to prominence=== [[File:Championship celebration Borussia Dortmund 2011.jpg|thumb|right|Borussia Dortmund players celebrate winning the Bundesliga in [[2010–11 Bundesliga|2011]].]] In the [[2009–10 Bundesliga|2009–10]] season, Klopp's Dortmund improved on the season before, finishing fifth in the Bundesliga to qualify for the [[2010–11 UEFA Europa League|UEFA Europa League]]. The team missed an opportunity to qualify for the Champions League when they did not beat eighth-place [[VfL Wolfsburg]] and 14th-place [[SC Freiburg]] in the final two matches of the campaign. Entering the [[2010–11 Bundesliga|2010–11]] season, Dortmund fielded a young and vibrant roster. On 4 December 2010, Borussia became ''[[Herbstmeister]]'' ("Autumn Champion"), an unofficial accolade going to the league leader at the winter break. They did this three matches before the break, sharing the record for having achieved this earliest with [[Eintracht Frankfurt]] (1993–94) and 1. FC Kaiserslautern (1997–98).{{cite web |url=http://www.focus.de/sport/fussball/bundesliga1/bundesliga-dortmund-vorzeitig-bundesliga-herbstmeister_aid_578667.html |title=Dortmund vorzeitig Bundesliga-Herbstmeister |author=sid |date=4 December 2010 |publisher=[[Focus (German magazine)|Focus]] online |language=de |access-date=5 December 2010 |archive-date=19 July 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719021743/http://www.focus.de/sport/fussball/bundesliga1/bundesliga-dortmund-vorzeitig-bundesliga-herbstmeister_aid_578667.html |url-status=live }} On 30 April 2011, the club beat [[1. FC Nürnberg]] 2–0 at home, while second-place Bayer Leverkusen lost, leaving Dortmund eight points clear with two games to play. This championship equalled the seven national titles held by rivals Schalke 04, and guaranteed a spot in the [[2011–12 UEFA Champions League|2011–12 Champions League]] group stages.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/feedarticle/9622741 |title=Borussia Dortmund wrap up Bundesliga title |date=30 April 2011 |work=The Guardian |access-date=1 May 2011}} One year later, Dortmund successfully defended of its Bundesliga title with a win over [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]], again on the 32nd match day. By the 34th and final match day, Dortmund had set a new record with the most points—81—gained by a club in one Bundesliga season.{{cite web |url=http://sportbild.bild.de/SPORT/bundesliga/2012/05/05/dortmund-freiburg/bvb-knackt-punkterekord.html |title=81 Punkte! During the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]], the stadium was referred to as "FIFA World Cup Stadium, Dortmund", while in UEFA club matches, it is known as "BVB Stadion Dortmund". The stadium currently{{when|date=January 2024}} hosts up to 81,359 spectators (standing and seated) for league matches and 65,829 seated spectators for international matches.{{contradictory inline|date=January 2024|article=Borussia Dortmund|section=Infobox}}{{cite web |url=http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/startseite/630989/artikel_dortmunds-stadionkapazitaet-erhoeht-sich.html |title=Dortmunds Stadionkapazität erhöht sich |language=de |date=16 July 2015 |publisher=Kicker |access-date=17 July 2015 |archive-date=8 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908174429/http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/startseite/630989/artikel_dortmunds-stadionkapazitaet-erhoeht-sich.html |url-status=live }}{{cite web |url=http://www.stadionwelt.de/sw_stadien/index.php?folder=sites&site=stadionguide_d&id=172 |title=SIGNAL IDUNA PARK, Borussia Dortmund |language=de |publisher=stadionwelt.de |access-date=26 July 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151127005809/http://www.stadionwelt.de/sw_stadien/index.php?folder=sites&site=stadionguide_d&id=172 |archive-date=27 November 2015 |url-status=dead }} For these, the characteristic southern grandstand is re-equipped with seats to conform to FIFA regulations. In 1974, the Westfalenstadion replaced the [[Stadion Rote Erde]], which is located next door and serves now as the stadium of [[Borussia Dortmund II]].{{citation needed|date=January 2024}} After the increasing popularity of Borussia Dortmund in the 1960s, it became obvious that the traditional ground was too small for the increasing number of Borussia Dortmund supporters. The city of Dortmund, however, was not able to finance a new stadium and federal institutions were unwilling to help. But in 1971, Dortmund was selected to replace the city of [[Cologne]], which was forced to withdraw its plans to host games in the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|1974 World Cup]]. The funds originally set aside for the projected stadium in Cologne were thus re-allocated to Dortmund, and a new stadium became reality. The Westfalenstadion has undergone several renovations throughout the years to increase the size of the stadium, including an expansion of the stadium for the 2006 World Cup. In 2008, the ''Borusseum'', a museum about Borussia Dortmund, opened in the stadium.{{Cite web|url=https://www.krafthaus.eu/en/borusseum-bvb-dortmund-09-football-museum/|title=Borusseum –BVB Dortmund 09 Football Museum|language=en-GB|access-date=6 December 2019|website=krafthaus.eu|archive-date=6 December 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191206130705/https://www.krafthaus.eu/en/borusseum-bvb-dortmund-09-football-museum/|url-status=live}} In 2011, Borussia Dortmund agreed to a partnership with [[Q-Cells]].
